occurrences.line_text: That now it gan to threaten neare decay:
But labour lost it was, to weene approch him neare.
That once hath failed of her souse full neare,
Whom such when Guyon saw, he drew him neare,
And to him beckned, to approch more neare,
But gathering him round about more neare,
Anone one sent out of the thicket neare
Who al this while lay bleeding out his hart-bloud neare.
He neare was touched in his noble spright,
From the sharpe Hauke, which her attached neare,
He was compeld to seeke some refuge neare,
That he has gotten to a forrest neare,
Vpon the grassy ground, and by him neare
Those feeling wordes so neare the quicke did goe,
Ne none can suffer to approchen neare:
That hauing once escaped perill neare,
What mote they be: who viewing them more neare
And ouerthrew, what euer came her neare,
Who soone as she him saw approaching neare
I cal'd her loud, I sought her farre and neare;
But that he her must hurt, or hazard neare:
Till she drew neare, and then againe remoue;
Of Amoret, so neare vnto decay,
Ouer his head, before the harme came neare.
But ere that it to him approched neare,
Till to his castle they approched neare.
Mongst men of worth, I to her stepped neare,
Yet farre and neare the Nymph his mother sought,
To which no wit of man may comen neare;
I will them tell though vnto no man neare:
And lowest hell, to which I lie most neare,
But Artegall pursewd him still so neare,
The sad effect of her neare ouerthrow;
In sdeignfull wize he drew vnto him neare,
To whom when he approched neare in sight,
And now the Knights being arriued neare,
Till thou haue tride againe, & tempted him more neare.
Yet when she reckned them, still drawing neare,
He comming neare, gan gently her salute,
Vppon two stubborne oakes, which stand so neare,
Which she accepting, he so neare her drew,
Hauing by chaunce espide aduantage neare,
In hope some stroke to fasten on him neare;
Can not come neare him in the couert wood,
Which when the Damzell neare at hand did spy,
The other on the other side, and neare them none.
With the neare touch whereof in tender hart
Ere that huge stroke arriued on him neare,
He drawing neare, began to greete them faire,
Abasht at his rebuke, that bit her neare,
Did forth descend, there being none them neare,
Weening her lifes last howre then neare to bee,
Vnder his stroke he to him stepping neare,
Was neare to Enuie, euen her neighbour next;
Then th'other comming neare, gan him reuile,
That first vnto his hand in chase did happen neare.
Thence they him carried to a Castle neare,
Yet knowing that her Knight now neare did draw,
At last some fisher barke doth neare behold,
With him to wend vnto his wonning neare:
And without weapon him assayling neare,
He sought him farre and neare, yet him no where he spyde.
And in some stable neare did set him vp to feede.
Approching to him neare, his hand he stayd,
Yet would not neare approch in daungers eye,
Which a straunge knight, that neare afore him went,
There when he saw those two so neare him stand,
He started vp, and snatching neare his syde
He left his lofty steede to aide him neare,
Now here, now there, and oft him neare he mist;
Was holpen vp, who him supported standing neare.
But when approching neare, he plainely found,
Whose sensefull words empierst his hart so neare,
Drew neare, that he the truth of all by him mote learne.
And searched all their cels and secrets neare;
But he him fast pursuing, soone approched neare.
But strained him so streightly, that he chokt him neare.
Yet thee fierce Fortune did so nearely driue,
When I should see, that would me nearer moue,
He closely nearer crept, the truth to weet:
Wherefore he stayd, till that he nearer drew,
Yet nought the nearer to his iourneys end;
And crost the nearest way, by which he cast
Doth hast to crosse him by the nearest way,
Her nearest handmayd, whom she most did trust,
Whereas the Heardes were keeping of their neat,
For his owne turne, yet inly neate and clene,
And vnder neath him his courageous steed,
Her neather partes misshapen, monstruous,
Her neather parts, the shame of all her kind,
Thrise seene the shadowes of the neather world,
But that this darksome neather world her light
His neather lip was not like man nor beast,
Or breake the chayne of strong necessitee,
And when they stood in most necessitee,
Who then can striue with strong necessitie,
Vnhappie falles that hard necessitie,
When as necessitie doth it constraine.
And serue their owne necessities with others need.
To Faerie Court, that of necessity
And yeeldes his caytiue neck to victours most despight.
About his neck an hempen rope he weares,
Vpon whose stubborne neck, whereat he raues
And snowy neckd Doris, and milkewhite Galathï¿½a.
And like a Crane his necke was long and fyne,
Who on his necke his bloudie clawes did seize,
Her necke and breasts were euer open bare,
And glauncing from his scaly necke, did glyde
On his horse necke before the quilted sell,
About her necke, or rings of rushes plight;
Vpon great Neptunes necke they softly swim,
His double folded necke she reard vpright,
About the turtles necke, that with the vew
And all about her necke and shoulders flew
And round about his necke an halter tight,
She lightly to him leapt, and in his necke
That his owne waight his necke asunder broke,
And in her necke a Castle huge had made,
There he the necke thereof did cut in twaine,
His foot he set on his vile necke, in signe
He in his necke had set his foote with fell disdaine.
Her yuorie necke, her alablaster brest,
That with one fall his necke he almost brake,
Fell straight about their neckes, as they did kneele,
Few drops, more cleare then Nectar, forth distild,
Then that sweet verse, with Nectar sprinckeled,
And euer with sweet Nectar she did sprinkle him.
They pourd in soueraine balme, and Nectar good,
In blessed Nectar, and pure Pleasures well,
Whose need had end, but no end couetise,
I no whit reck, ne you the like need to reherce.
And eke this battels end, will need another place.
His mightie armour, missing most at need;
Nor aid enuy to him, in need that stands,
Thou wretched man, of death hast greatest need,
He feard not once him selfe to be in need,
He had enough, what need him care for more?
What need of armes, where peace doth ay remaine,
And shall find friends, if need requireth soe,
Hard helpe at need. So deare thee babe I bought,
And of her plenty adde vnto their need:
Should need of all his armes, him to defend;
The measure of her meane, and naturall first need.
All that I need I haue; what needeth mee
How that straunge sword refusd, to serue his need,
To whom the Infant thus, Faire Sir, what need
With hookes and ladles, as need did require;
May often need the helpe of weaker hand;
At need, till now, he lightly threw away,
Him faild thereto, and serued not his need,
Need but behold the pourtraict of her hart,
Daughter (said she) what need ye be dismayd,
More need of leach-craft hath your Damozell,
And our weake hands (whom need new strength shall teach)
She shortly thus; Fly they, that need to fly;
What had th'eternall Maker need of thee,
Withouten pleasure: ne her need implore
But so much as doth need, must needs be counted here.
Ne doe they need with water of the ford,
Need teacheth her this lesson hard and rare,
No need to bid her fast away to flie;
Was for like need enforst to disaray:
The louing couple need no reskew feare,
Yet his owne face was dreadfull, ne did need
It shall not fayle, when so ye shall it need.
Walkt through the wood, for pleasure, or for need;
For loue of Nymphes she thought she need not care,
Thereof make tryall, in my greatest need:
What other meed then need me to requight,
(Said Burbon) to assist me now at need
Toward the Castle, where if need constraine,
Yet since ye mercie now doe need to craue,
Into some forrein land, where as no need
Done to that wounded Knight in his great need,
And had he not in his extreamest need,
Them wont to weare, and wend on foot for need,
To whom she thus, What need me Sir to tell,
Nathlesse (quoth he) if need doe not you bynd,
Which to redresse, she did th'assistance need
But sith we need good counsell (sayd the swaine)
Would not her leaue alone in her great need.
Which if they would afford him ayde at need
And serue their owne necessities with others need.
The knight was nothing nice, where was no need,
So taught of nature, which doth litle need
And otherwhiles for need, he did assay
Thereto feare gaue her wings, and neede her courage taught.
Such, as no doubt of him he neede misdeeme.
Was dead with feare, nathlesse as neede required,
In no lesse neede of helpe, then him he weend.
But now of Britomart it here doth neede,
But neede, that answers not to all requests,
And to the present neede it wisely vsd.
Here neede you to remember, how erewhile
Did neede to gard from force, or secret theft
Him for to aide, if aide he chaunst to neede,
By law of armes there neede ones right to trie,
Had neede haue mightie hands, for to fulfill
With hope of helpe in that her greatest neede.
Besought of courtesie in that his neede,
Till that at length, in his extreamest neede,
Finde harbour fit to comfort her great neede.
As he vnable were for very neede
His long endured famine needed more reliefe.
Him needed not long call, she soone to hond
Me litle needed from my right way to haue straid.
Yet sithens helpe, he saw, he needed more
Of all, that needed them to be inquird,
Th'old woman nought, that needed, did omit;
Him needed not instruct, which way were best
That needed much her weake age to desire,
Else should he thrise haue needed, for the nonce
And rather needed to be disciplinde
Thereto, when needed, she could weepe and pray,
With needelesse dread, till certaintie ye heare:
Whose onely ioy was to relieue the needes
But death will neuer come, when needes require.
Else mote it needes downe to his manly brest
Here needes me, whiles the famous auncestries
We needes must passe (God do vs well acquight,)
In the wide sea, they needes must passen by,
And wilfull want, all carelesse of her needes;
Sith then (said Braggadocchio) needes thou wilt
To house a guest, that would be needes obayd,
Some blisfull houres at last must needes appeare;
Vnto your losse: and now needes will ye sleepe?
That if two met, the one mote needes fall ouer the lidge.
Yet if he needes will fight, craue leaue till morne,
Would needes depart, as shall declared be elsewhere.
That rather needes wise read and discipline,
But that I needes must by all meanes fulfill
Now needeth him no lenger labour spend,
For them most needeth comfort in the end,
All that I need I haue; what needeth mee
Ah Nurse, what needeth thee to eke my paine?
Two eyes him needeth, for to watch and wake,
To stirre vp strife, when most vs needeth rest,
Him needeth sure a golden pen I weene,
Begets and eke conceiues, ne needeth other none.
Onely what needeth, shall be here fulfild,
To whom the Prince; Certes me needeth more
And needeth safegard now vpon her way,
When day is spent, and rest vs needeth most,
In this exploite, me needeth to declare,
Voide of all succour and needfull comfort:
Both were full loth to leaue that needfull tent,
And seru'd of all things that mote needfull bee;
With more then needfull naturall remorse,
He all things did puruay, which for them needfull weare.
Ye may doe well in this her needfull state
But naked without needfull vestiments,
Whose burden mote empeach his needfull speed,
Whereof she glad, now needing strong defence,
The which did her co[m]maund, without needing perswade.
The mortall sting his angry needle shot
To finger the fine needle and nyce thread;
More sharpe then points of needles did proceede,
And to the Dwarfe a while his needlesse spere he gaue.
Ne let vaine feares procure your needlesse smart,
Whose needlesse dread for to remoue away,
For needlesse feare did neuer vantage none,
From needlesse trouble of renewing fight
And wast thy ioyous houres in needlesse paine,
Long worke it were, and needlesse to deuize
To doe away vaine doubt, and needlesse dreed:
To peace, then needlesse trouble to constraine.
Both speare and shield, as things that needlesse were,
Of needments at his backe. Thus as they past,
His scrip did hang, in which his needments he did bind.
Die shall all flesh? what then must needs be donne,
What needs me tell their feast and goodly guize,
What needs of daintie dishes to deuize,
For which what needs me fetch from Faery
So that needs loue or death must be thy lot,
Glauce, what needs this colourable word,
Or what needs her to toyle, sith fates can make
Cannot endure, but needs it must be wrackt
But so much as doth need, must needs be counted here.
Ne needs there Gardiner to set, or sow,
Therefore needs mote he liue, that liuing giues to all.
To tell (quoth she) that which ye see, needs not;
And if it chaunst, (as needs it must in fight)
When so it needs with rigour to dispence.
Then sith ye needs (quoth he) will know my shame,
That I would hide, will needs, I see, be rad.
That way, (and yet they needs must passe that way),
When so she lagged, as she needs mote so,
Sith then ye needs will know the griefe I hoord,
By straunge occasion, that here needs forth be set.
For greater force there needs to maintaine wrong, then right.
And needs with him streight to the place would ryde,
Could not maligne him, but commend him needs:
It could not boot, needs mote she die at last:
To call in-commers by, that needy were and pore.
Nathelesse the Knight now in so needy case,
Furthest from end then, when they neerest weene,
And so did warlike Antony neglect
Which softly ecchoed from the neighbour wood;
The neighbour woods around with hollow murmur ring.
His neighbour element in his reuenge:
Of neighbour Scots, and forrein Scatterlings,
Then came his neighbour flouds, which nigh him dwell,
Was neare to Enuie, euen her neighbour next;
And ioyne in neighbourhood of kingdome nere,
Far from all neighbourhood, the which annoy it may.
At neighbours wealth, that made him euer sad;
Most enuious man, that grieues at neighbours good,
Far from all neighbours, that her deuilish deedes
Into their neighbours borders; ne did giue
Vpon their neighbours, which did nigh them border,
A trampling steede, that with his neighing fast
But neither darkenesse fowle, nor filthy bands,
His harder hide would neither perce, nor bight,
But neither silke nor siluer therein did appeare.
So bids thee well to fare, Thy neither friend, nor foe, Fidessa.
That me he knew not, neither his owne ille;
Neither to melt in pleasures whot desire,
For neither doth thy face terrestriall shew,
Yet neither spinnes nor cardes, ne cares nor frets,
Whom neither wind out of their seat could forse,
The vertue is, that neither steele, nor stone
On either side, that neither mayle could hold,
That neither could his mightie puissance sustaine.
Neither vnseemely short, nor yet exceeding long.
For neither can he fly, nor other harme,
But neither toyle nor trauell might her backe recoyle.
That neither guile, nor force might it distraine.
She woxe; yet wist she neither how, nor why,
But neither God of loue, nor God of sky
But they that die, doe neither loue nor hate.
That neither bloud in face, nor life in hart
Which earst to you I playnd: for neither may
His garment neither was of silke nor say,
Neither of idle shewes, nor of false charmes aghast.
Neither of them she found where she them lore:
But either he should neither of them haue, or both.
That neither plate nor mayle, whereas their powre
Whiles neither lets the other touch the soyle,
That neither could the others force sustaine;
Which neither able were to wag, or once to weld.
That neither could in hast themselues againe vpreare.
Yet neither toyle nor griefe she once did spare,
That neither day nor night from working spared,
Whence neither greatly hasted to arise,
Whose raging rigour neither steele nor bras
Yet neither shewed to other their hearts priuity.
Yet neither would their fiendlike fury slacke,
I neither can my loue, ne yet my life forgo.
For neither pretious stone, nor durefull brasse,
For when as neither gifts nor graces kind
That neither yron barres, nor brasen locke
For neither he did shed that Ladies bloud,
Sith neither force of stones which they did throw,
And broke their speares; yet neither has forgon
Since neither is endamadg'd much thereby.
That neither hath religion nor fay,
Yet neither Ino, nor Medea stout,
For neither will one foot, till we that carle haue hent.
As neither glad nor sorie for their sight;
Whom neither dread of God, that deuils bindes,
That neither could the others stroke sustaine,
Neither of other taking pitty nor remorse.
Sayd then Sir Calidore; Neither will I
For he regarded neither playnt nor teare,
Did taste of pittie, neither gentlesse knew,
Regarding neither speare, that mote him slay,
For their bad Stuard neither plough'd nor sowed,
Vnarm'd, as fearing neither foe nor frend,
Then North; then neither, but as fortune fell.
For neither they by force could him destroy,
Swore by his sword, that neither day nor weeke
Yet neither she for him, nor other none
That neither could to company of th'other creepe.
Neleus and Pelias louely brethren both;
Gaynd in Nemea goodly victoree;
And Nemertea learned well to rule her lust.
Into the great Nemoean lions groue.
Or a war-monger to be basely nempt;
And next to him the Nene downe softly slid;
Of hardy Nennius, whom he yet did slay,
The which was with Nepenthe to the brim vpfild.
Nepenthe is a drinck of souerayne grace,
To doen his Nephew in all riches flow;
Why suffredst thou thy Nephewes deare to fall
But from the grandsyre to the Nephewes sonne,
By dew successe, and all their Nephewes late,
When two of three her Nephews are so fowle forlorne?
But what art thou, that telst of Nephews kilt?
He would at her request prolong her nephews daies.
He hurles out vowes, and Neptune oft doth blesse:
And rolling downe, great Neptune doth dismay;
Ne swelling Neptune, ne loud thundring Ioue
Or wrathfull Neptune did them driue before
Great Neptune, I auow to hallow vnto thee.
Great Neptune stood amazed at their sight,
Next vnto him was Neptune pictured,
For losse of his deare loue by Neptune hent,
First came great Neptune with his threeforkt mace,
Yet sonnes of Neptune, now assembled here:
For Albion the sonne of Neptune was,
Which from great Neptune do deriue their parentage.
But vnto great king Neptune selfe did goe,
To whom God Neptune softly smyling, thus;
Vpon great Neptunes necke they softly swim,
And hath the charge of Neptunes mightie heard;
Liues still: and to this feast with Neptunes seed was dight.
Did faire auoide the violence him nere;
And suffred not their blowes to byte him nere
Which with great vprore preaced to draw nere
To seeke the fugitiue, both farre and nere,
Long he her sought, he sought her farre and nere,
And shrieking Hububs them approching nere,
Wouen with gold and silke so close and nere,
Throwes forth vpon the riuage round about him nere.
Full glad of so good end, to them drew nere,
Her worke, and counterfet her selfe so nere,
And ioyne in neighbourhood of kingdome nere,
And weighed out in ballaunces so nere,
But she, whose Princely breast was touched nere
The which with mortall malice him pursu'd so nere.
All sodainely out of the forrest nere
Had left that couple, nere their vtmost cast.
When she was slaine, or had bene to her succour nere.
And all that nere him came, did hew and slay,
Vnto the Prince of Picteland bordering nere,
A thousand times she her embraced nere,
Whom of their sire Nereides men call,
And Nereus crownes with cups; his mates him pledg around.
The daughter of great Nereus, which did beare
Thy Gransire Nereus promist to adorne?
Of all which Nereus th'eldest, and the best,
Proud Priams towne. So wise is Nereus old,
All these the daughters of old Nereus were,
And Neso, and Eione well in age,
Was woxen strong, and left her fruitfull nest;
Or in his wombe might lurke some hidden nest
She staid: with that he crauld out of his nest,
Emongst wide waues set, like a litle nest,
The life did flit away out of her nest,
And safe commit to her soft fethered nest,
Feeling her leape out of her loathed nest,
In his free thought to build her sluggish nest:
And loue for to dislodge out of his nest:
And out of that same fishers filthy nest
They spide a little cottage, like some poore mans nest.
Or litle sparrowes, stolen from their nest,
With which he streight went to the Captaines nest.
The yeares of Nestor nothing were to his,
Wondred Agaue, Poris, and Nesï¿½a,
Her cunning web, and spred her subtile net,
A subtile net, which onely for the same
For that same net so cunningly was wound,
Into his hidden net full easily doth fall.
A net in th'one hand, and a rustie blade
Her brest all naked, as net iuory,
Als at his backe a great wyde net he bore,
He suddenly his net vpon her threw,
To whom the Priest with naked armes full net
That nether Phoebus beams could through the[m] throng,
They all were fled for feare, but whether, nether kond.
Nether of enuy, nor of chaunge afeard,
Nor the fine nets, which oft we wouen see
The whiles his nets were drying on the sand:
Thus finely did he his false nets dispred,
There all her subtill nets she did vnfold,
How he his nets doth for their ruine lay:
Another while I baytes and nets display,
Yet armes till that time did he neuer wield:
The vine-prop Elme, the Poplar neuer dry,
And low, where dawning day doth neuer peepe,
That was in Ocean waues yet neuer wet,
Yet she her weary limbes would neuer rest,
Was neuer Prince so faithfull and so faire,
Was neuer Prince so meeke and debonaire;
With him away, but yet could neuer win
Vnder them neuer sat, ne wont there sound
Did neuer mortall eye behold such heauenly grace.
Yet neuer shew of liuing wight espyde;
And fled away: for neuer in that land
But knight he now shall neuer more deface:
Yet wilfull man he neuer would forecast,
He neuer meant with words, but swords to plead his right.
Of deare Sansfoy, I neuer ioyed howre,
For needlesse feare did neuer vantage none,
Can neuer rest, vntill it forth haue brought
That Phoebus chearefull face durst neuer vew,
For neuer did such brightnesse there appeare,
Yet pittie in her hart was neuer proued
Till then: for euermore she hated, neuer loued.
The wakefull dogs did neuer cease to bay,
Descends to hell: there creature neuer past,
Great paines, & greater praise, both neuer to be donne.
Yet crime in her could neuer creature find,
Whose like he neuer saw, he durst not bide,
But Venus neuer had so sober mood;
In which his might was neuer ouerthrowne,
Whose like in womens wit he neuer knew;
That Redcrosse knight, perdie, I neuer slew,
His liuing like saw neuer liuing eye,
Was neuer Ladie loued dearer day,
